metadata.description: This data set was derived from MODIS version 005 and the IMS data set. It is a daily cloudless snow area product processed by cloud removal. Value range: 0%-100%. 200: snow; 100: lake ice; 25: land; 37: sea. The spatial resolution is 0.005 degrees (approximately 500 m), and the temporal coverage is from July 5, 2002, to December 31, 2014.

background: Mid-latitude Alpine snow cover is characterized by rapid seasonal changes and large spatial variations, which play important roles in energy changes, climate, water resources and ecological processes (Dozier and Painter2004). Known as Asia’s water tower, the glaciers and snowpack over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP) provide the headwater for several major rivers in Asia (Xu, Ramanathan, and Washington2016). The water supplied by this region affects approximately 50–60% of the world’s population in China and parts of Asia (Barnett, Adam, and Lettenmaier 2005). Snow cover maps provide information about the spatial extent of the snow cover and are very useful for snow-related research. The snow cover on the plateau has important influences on the atmospheric circulation in the northern hemisphere but also directly affect the climatic and eco-environmental evolution of China (Qin, Liu, and Li2006). Due to the remoteness, topographic complexity and the relative sparsity of meteorological observation over the QTP, remote sensing is the most practical tool for monitoring a snow-covered area over the QTP. Although the snow algorithm developed by the MODIS data group can separate snow from the most obscuring clouds, daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction (as high as 47.3% over the QTP according to Tang et al. (2013). The first cloud-free snow cover products were derived from the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System of the NOAA/NESDIS (Brown et al.2014). The other three snow cover products (MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B, TAI) are essentially produced by MODIS snow cover data.
research objective: The aim of this study is to provide a quantitative assessment of the performance of the currently available four daily cloud-free snow cover products and which product is more efficient for use in hydrologic and climatological applications over the QTP. Based on the assessment, an I-TAI (Improvement of Terra–Aqua–IMS) snow product was proposed, which can improve the accuracy to some extent.
challenges: However, the algorithms of the MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the QTP. The snow misclassification is an important limitation of MODIS snow cover products and requires additional improvements. Although the snow algorithm developed by the MODIS data group can separate snow from the most obscuring clouds, daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction (as high as 47.3% over the QTP according to Tang et al. (2013). Cloud cover can significantly limit the application of MODIS snow products (López-Burgos, Gupta, and Clark2013; Parajka and Blöschl 2006; Wang et al.2009).
methods: The third step was to identify perennial snow/ice and land cover based on elevation. When the cloud pixels were at elevations higher than 5800 m, they could also be assigned to a snow-covered pixel. The fourth step was based on the spatial combination of adjacent pixels. Four direct‘side-bordering’ adjacent pixels of the cloud pixel were examined. If at least three of four pixels are defined as snow, then the cloud pixel was also assigned to snow. The last steps adopt the model of the snowline. The aim of this step was to identify the minimum elevation where snow exists and the snow-covered elevation where all pixels above this level were covered by snow. Next, these elevation lines are set as threshold elevations to remove the cloud pixels. The first step consists of the Terra/Aqua combination described above, and the second step is the combination of MODIS images and IMS data.
dataset: In situ measurements of snow depth were provided by the meteorological stations’ network maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA). In this study, snow depths from 91 meteorological stations in the study area were used that were obtained between 2004 and 2014 (downloaded from the CMA Sharing Service System athttp:// cdc.cma.gov.cn). The elevations of the meteorological stations ranged from 1400 to 4900 m, and the average elevation was approximately 3500 m. The first snow cover products are the IMS products of the NOAA/NESDIS (Ramsay1998). The MODIS snow products utilized the Terra/Aqua combination and temporal combination algorithm (Parajka and Blöschl2008).
findings: Comparisons of the IMS, MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B and TAI cloud-free snow products against meteorological stations observations over 10 snow seasons (2004–2013) over the QTP indicated overall accuracies of 76.0%, 89.3%, 92.0% and 92.0%, respectively. The Khat values of the IMS, MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B and TAI products were 0.084, 0.463, 0.428 and 0.526, respectively. The TAI products appear to have the best cloud-removal ability among the four snow products over the QTP.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a data collection challenge when monitoring snow cover in the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in monitoring snow cover is the presence of high cloud-covered fractions in daily MODIS data, often as high as 47.3% over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. This cloud cover significantly limits the application of MODIS snow products, necessitating advanced algorithms to separate snow from obscuring clouds.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of remote sensing in monitoring snow-covered areas over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing is the most practical tool for monitoring snow-covered areas over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau due to the region's remoteness, topographic complexity, and the relative sparsity of meteorological observation.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges faced by MODIS series products in snow cover classification over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, and the snow misclassification is an important limitation requiring additional improvements.

Definition.Question: What is the methodological approach used to achieve cloud-free snow cover datasets?
Definition.Answer: The methodological approach includes the Terra/Aqua combination, the combination of MODIS images and IMS data, and steps to identify perennial snow/ice and land cover based on elevation and spatial combination of adjacent pixels to remove cloud pixels.

Comparison.Question: How does the cloud-removal ability of the TAI cloud-free snow product compare to that of the MOD-SSM/I and MOD-B products over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP)?
Comparison.Answer: The TAI cloud-free snow product has the best cloud-removal ability among the four snow products over the QTP, with a Khat value of 0.526 compared to 0.463 for MOD-SSM/I and 0.428 for MOD-B.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between the in situ measurements of snow depth by the China Meteorological Administration and the MODIS snow products?
Comparison.Answer: In situ measurements of snow depth are collected from meteorological stations, while MODIS snow products utilize remote sensing data from Terra/Aqua satellites and employ algorithms to separate snow from clouds.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of the 三江源积雪面积遥感产品 compare to that of the IMS products of NOAA/NESDIS?
Comparison.Answer: The 三江源积雪面积遥感产品 has a spatial resolution of 0.005 degrees (approximately 500m), whereas the IMS products' resolution is not specified in the provided content, but they are generally known to have coarser resolution compared to MODIS-based products.

Interpretation.Question: How can remote sensing data be effectively used to overcome the challenges of cloud cover in snow cover mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing data, such as MODIS and IMS, can be used in combination to address cloud cover challenges. Techniques like cloud pixel reassignment based on elevation and spatial combination of adjacent pixels are applied to discern snow cover from cloud cover, improving the accuracy of snow cover mapping in regions like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred for improving the accuracy of snow cover products in regions with complex topography?
Interpretation.Answer: Improving the accuracy of snow cover products can involve using elevation-based methods to identify snow-covered pixels, integrating multiple data sources like Terra/Aqua MODIS and IMS, and employing algorithms like the snowline model to define snow-covered elevations and remove cloud pixels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the instability in algorithms when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The instability is caused by the limitations in the MODIS series products, which have difficulty accurately classifying wet snow and snow under forest cover. Additionally, the high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data poses a challenge, as clouds significantly obscure the snow cover, limiting the effectiveness of these products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is remote sensing considered the most practical tool for monitoring snow-covered areas over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing is the most practical tool due to the remoteness and topographic complexity of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, combined with the sparse distribution of meteorological observation stations. These factors make ground-based monitoring challenging, so satellite data offers a more feasible and comprehensive approach for monitoring snow cover in this region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons that cloud cover significantly limits the application of MODIS snow products over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The significant limitation is due to the high cloud-covered fraction, which can be as high as 47.3% over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. This cloud cover obscures the snow, making it difficult for MODIS algorithms to accurately detect snow cover, thus requiring additional methods or products to improve cloud removal and increase the accuracy of snow detection.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on snow cover monitoring accuracy when utilizing in situ snow depth measurements from meteorological stations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing in situ snow depth measurements from meteorological stations enhances snow cover monitoring accuracy by providing ground-truth data that can validate and calibrate remote sensing products. This approach helps in refining the snow cover models and algorithms, leading to more reliable snow cover maps.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives behind developing cloud-free snow cover products for the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to provide a quantitative assessment of the performance of the currently available four daily cloud-free snow cover products and determine which product is more efficient for use in hydrologic and climatological applications over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. An improved snow product, I-TAI, was proposed to enhance accuracy.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate Terra/Aqua MODIS data with IMS data in snow cover mapping over complex terrains?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of Terra/Aqua MODIS data with IMS data is crucial to improve cloud removal capabilities and provide more accurate mapping of snow cover, especially in regions like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau where traditional methods face challenges due to high cloud cover and complex topography.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of using elevation-based algorithms in identifying snow cover from remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of using elevation-based algorithms is to enhance the accuracy of snow cover detection by identifying the minimum elevation where snow exists and determining the snow-covered elevation, thereby removing cloud pixels that could otherwise lead to misclassification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in creating a cloud-free snow cover dataset from MODIS and IMS data for the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves several steps: First is the Terra/Aqua combination of MODIS images with IMS data. Next, the elevation-based identification of perennial snow/ice and land cover is carried out. Cloud pixels at elevations higher than 5800 m can be assigned as snow-covered. The spatial combination of adjacent pixels is then examined, where if at least three out of four adjacent pixels are defined as snow, the cloud pixel is also assigned to snow. Finally, the snowline model is used to determine threshold elevations for removing cloud pixels.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges in applying MODIS snow cover algorithms in regions with complex topography like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, and how might these be addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the instability of MODIS algorithms in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover, as well as high cloud cover obscuring snow detection. To address these, procedural improvements such as using the Terra/Aqua combination, IMS data integration, and elevation-based cloud pixel reclassification are applied. The I-TAI snow product is proposed to enhance accuracy and reduce misclassification.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the reduction of cloud cover interference in remote sensing snow cover products over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies include the Terra/Aqua combination, spatial combination of adjacent pixels, and the use of elevation thresholds to identify snow-covered areas for cloud pixel removal.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be instability in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover using remote sensing data in mid-latitude alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: The algorithms of the MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, which is an important limitation of MODIS snow cover products and requires additional improvements.

Expectation.Answer: Daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction, as high as 47.3% over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, which significantly limits the application of MODIS snow products due to the remoteness and topographic complexity of the area.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional in situ measurements of snow depth be insufficient for accurate snow cover mapping in remote high-altitude regions?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the relative sparsity of meteorological observation over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, traditional in situ measurements might be insufficient, making remote sensing the most practical tool for monitoring snow-covered areas.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of current data collection methods in capturing snow cover in challenging terrains like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of current data collection methods is limited by challenges such as high cloud cover and topographic complexity. Remote sensing, particularly through MODIS, offers practical solutions, but the cloud cover remains a significant issue, affecting data accuracy and requiring innovative cloud-removal techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using only remote sensing data for snow cover analysis in the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing data, while valuable, face limitations such as instability in algorithms for distinguishing wet snow and snow under forest cover. Additionally, the high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data limits its application, necessitating supplementary data or methods to improve accuracy.

Assertion.Answer: Although the MODIS data group developed an algorithm to separate snow from clouds, daily MODIS data still have a high cloud-covered fraction, as high as 47.3% over the QTP. This cloud cover can significantly limit the application of MODIS snow products.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how elevation factors into the identification of snow-covered areas in remote sensing data collection.
Assertion.Answer: In the data collection method, cloud pixels at elevations higher than 5800 m could be assigned to a snow-covered pixel. Additionally, spatial combinations of adjacent pixels are used, and snowlines are modeled to set threshold elevations for removing cloud pixels.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a detailed analysis of the challenges faced in snow cover data collection in the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau and suggest methodologies to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in snow cover data collection over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau include instability in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover, as well as a high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data. These issues lead to snow misclassification, limiting the application of MODIS snow products. To overcome these challenges, methodologies such as the spatial combination of adjacent pixels and the use of elevation models can be applied. Specifically, cloud pixels at elevations higher than 5800 m can be assigned to snow-covered pixels, and cloud pixels surrounded by snow can be classified as snow. Additionally, setting threshold elevations to remove cloud pixels and combining Terra/Aqua MODIS images with IMS data are effective strategies to enhance data accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a research approach to improve the accuracy of cloud-free snow cover products using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: To improve the accuracy of cloud-free snow cover products, a research approach could involve developing an integrated algorithm that combines various data sources and methods. This approach could include the Terra/Aqua combination with temporal algorithms, spatial analysis techniques like the spatial combination of adjacent pixels, and elevation threshold models. Additionally, the integration of MODIS data with IMS data and leveraging ground-based snow depth measurements from meteorological stations can provide validation and calibration of remote sensing products. By refining the existing algorithms and incorporating multi-sensor data, researchers can enhance the cloud-removal capabilities and overall accuracy of snow cover products.
